Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: A family has requested a final, mandatory preparation session for their child's imminent and significant religious sacrament.
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat with my step-siblings lighting up with reminders about tonight’s family dinner. My stepmother had emphasized how important it was for me to be there, especially since we hadn’t all gathered in months. I could almost hear her voice, gentle but firm, reminding me that being present was part of being family now. At the same time, my parish office phone blinked with a voicemail from the Martinez family. Their daughter’s sacrament was this weekend, and they needed me to lead a final, mandatory preparation session tonight—the only time their whole family could attend. As a priest, I knew how much this moment meant to them, how the Church expected me to guide and support my parishioners, especially at such milestones. My chest tightened as I weighed the two calls on my time and heart. I wanted to be the reliable step-sibling my family hoped for, but I also felt the sacred responsibility to my parish. The clock ticked on, and I sat frozen, torn between two worlds, each demanding my presence, each expecting my devotion.
